column1: Coos Bay (Coos language: Atsixiis) is a city located in Coos County
column3: United States
column4: where the Coos River enters Coos Bay on the Pacific Ocean. The city borders the city of North Bend
column5: and together they are often referred to as one entity called either Coos Bay-North Bend or Oregon's Bay Area. Coos Bay's population as of the 2010 census was 15
column6: 967 residents
column7: making it the most populous city on the Oregon Coast. Oregon's Bay Area is estimated to be home to 32

column1: Prior to Europeans first visiting the Oregon coast
column2: Native American tribes claimed the Coos Bay region as their homeland for thousands of years. Members of the Coos
column3: Lower Umpqua
column4: Siuslaw and Coquille tribes lived
column5: fished
column6: hunted and gathered along Coos Bay and its estuaries
column8: and in meadows and forests. Approximately 400 years ago
column9: British and Spanish explorers first approached the South Coast. In 1579
column10: Sir Francis Drake was purported to have sought shelter for his ship
column12: around Cape Arago. Trader and explorer Jedediah Smith was in the region seeking furs
column13: and the Hudson's Bay Company sent Alexander Roderick McLeod to search for an inland passage.

column1: The earliest settlement of European Americans in the area was in January 1852 when survivors of the Captain Lincoln shipwreck established Camp Castaway until they and their cargo could be fully rescued. There has been a permanent settlement on Coos Bay since 1853
column2: when the town of Marshfield was founded there and named after the Massachusetts hometown of its founder
column3: J. C. Tolman. The first Methodist church in the area was established in 1857. By 1866 the inhabitants
column4: who were reliant on the sea for their income
column5: had built the Cape Arago Light. The setting up of a post office in 1871 and the arrival of the Coos Bay Wagon Road in the town a year later connected Coos County with the Umpqua River valley in neighboring Douglas County
column6: on the other side of the Coast Range of mountains. This wagon road
column7: although long gone in its original form
column8: is still partially in existence since the route of Oregon Route 42 roughly follows the original right of way.

column1: 1870 saw Coos Bay set up its first
column3: chartered Masonic Lodge. Named Blanco Lodge
column4: this brotherhood was set up by several of the town's founding fathers. With this development
column5: the incorporation of Marshfield came in 1874. One of the nation's oldest still-operating machine shops
column6: the Nelson Machine Works-Coos Bay Iron Works

column3: the only lynching ever to be documented in Oregon occurred in Coos Bay
column4: of Alonzo Tucker
column5: an African American man. He was accused of raping a white woman and escaping from jail.  However
column6: there is no record of his escape from jail. According to newspaper accounts
column7: Tucker was discovered by two young boys who began shooting him with airguns. After a brief pursuit
column8: local miners apprehended Tucker who was hiding inside a store. The mob considering hanging him inside the store but decided to return him to the site of the alleged rape at a nearby bridge. Tucker was shot twice and then hung from the 7th Street bridge
column10: where high school soccer games are now held.  No charges were ever brought against the mob as officials determined "the deceased came to his death at the hands of parties unknown while resisting arrest for a felony
column11: and that no crime was committed thereby." Despite this claim that those in the mob were unknown
column13: including the husband of the alleged rape victim
column14: was noted in local newspapers. One newspaper at that time reported the mob was "quiet and orderly" and another paper wrote
column15: "'Well done' is the consensus of public opinion." Alonzo Tucker's cause of death was asphyxiation. According to the coroner's report
column16: cause of death was blood loss from the gunshot wound in Tucker’s right thigh
column17: in which case he died before being hanged on the Marshfield bridge.

column2: the Coos region was largely isolated from the rest of Oregon due to difficulties in crossing the Coast Range and fording rivers
column3: and the Pacific Ocean was used to link people to other areas
column4: including San Francisco
column5: which was an easier two-day trip compared to traveling inland over rugged terrain. In 1916 a rail line was completed that linked the region to other interior settlements and towns
column6: which increased commercial trade and tourism Significant urban growth occurred in the 1920s
column7: and during the 1930s to 1950s large-scale growth occurred. Per the Oregon Bay Area Chamber of Commerce

column1: Shipyards contracted with the U.S. Government to build minesweepers and rescue tugs for World War II defense purposes. Large national lumber companies set up operations and expanded significantly for the next two decades. Jetty improvements
column3: and crabbing shaped the development of Charleston. The completion of the North Bend Bridge (now McCullough Memorial Bridge) in 1936 and the Roosevelt Highway significantly improved modern transportation connections and provided the final link in opening the Coos region to the outside world. The formerly remote district known as the Coos Bay country had come of age.

column3: a Japanese ship named the New Carissa ran aground on a beach 2.75 miles (4.3 km) north of the entrance to Coos Bay
column4: drawing international attention to the area. The New Carissa was empty of cargo at the time
column5: heading for the Port of Coos Bay to pick up wood chips. When the captain was told that the weather was too severe for the ship to enter port
column6: he anchored his ship close by. The crew put out only one anchor
column7: and it appears that this was probably on too short a chain to be effective. The subsequent US Coast Guard investigation found several other aspects of the ship's company's handling of the situation to have been poor
column8: leading to the conclusion that human error caused the grounding. 70
column9: 000 US gallons (260 m3) of fuel oil were spilled by the vessel
column12: 000 gallons (625 to 965 m3) being deliberately set alight and burnt off later. The stern of the ship remained on the beach; the bow was towed out to sea and sunk after structural damage caused by the fire split the ship in two. In 2008
column13: the stern of the New Carissa was cut into pieces and removed from the beach.

column1: The worst loss of life for a fire department in modern Oregon history occurred in Coos Bay on November 25
column3: when three firefighters were killed by a structural failure of the roof in an auto parts store. The accidental blaze paralyzed the city for several hours
column4: with fire departments from several neighboring towns assisting in the effort to stop the blaze. Captain Randy Carpenter
column5: Firefighter/Engineer Robert "Chuck" Hanners and Firefighter/Engineer Jeff Common
column6: all from Coos Bay
column7: died when an explosion caused the roof of the building to cave in; they were inside the structure when the roof collapsed

column2: the city has a total area of 15.90 square miles (41.18 km2)
column3: of which
column4: 10.60 square miles (27.45 km2) is land and 5.30 square miles (13.73 km2) is water. The city is quite hilly
column5: with elevations ranging from between sea level to over 500 feet (150 m). Bodies of water within the city limits include Upper Pony Creek Reservoir

column1: The City of Coos Bay comprises four districts
column2: two of which (Eastside and Empire) were formerly independent cities.

column1: The Marshfield District of Coos Bay is the historic central downtown and business district of the city. Old Marshfield and its surrounding neighborhoods were what comprised the original Coos Bay before the annexations of Empire and Eastside during the 20th century. The Marshfield District contains many buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column3: Chandler Hotel
column4: Egyptian Theatre and Tioga Hotel. The waterfront area of the Marshfield District has a boardwalk with a city dock
column5: bicycling trail and pavilions featuring historical and interpretive displays.

column1: The Milner Crest district is a residential neighborhood developed in the mid-20th century
column2: located at the crest of a hill overlooking the bay
column3: north of Mingus Park and the Marshfield District. The majority of the Coos Bay area's medical facilities are located in this district.

column1: The Eastside district of Coos Bay was originally called East Marshfield for its situation on the east side of the bay. East Marshfield post office was established in 1891 and it operated intermittently until 1908
column2: when the name was changed to Eastside. The community of Eastside merged with the city of Coos Bay in 1983. Eastside is primarily a residential neighborhood and is home to Millicoma Middle School
column3: walking trails at Millicoma Marsh and a public boat launch.

column1: The Empire district (Coos language: Hanisich) was founded as Empire City in 1853 by members of the Coos Bay Company from Jacksonville
column3: and at the time it was assumed that the area would be center of the region. The company was formed after the discovery of gold in northern California and southwestern Oregon. For a time Empire City was the county seat of Coos County. The first post office in the location was called Elkhorn
column4: which ran from 1853 until 1854. It was the first post office in what is now Coos County
column5: though at the time it was part of Umpqua County. Empire City post office was established in 1858 and ran until 1894
column6: when it was renamed Empire. In 1965
column7: the city of Empire voted to consolidate with Coos Bay. Today
column8: Empire is the location of Madison Elementary School
column9: Sunset Intermediate School and a business district along Cape Arago Highway.

column1: This region experiences cool-to-warm summers typical of the Oregon coast
column2: with no average monthly temperatures above 71.6 °F (22.0 °C) which means mild weather usually in the lower 40s to upper 60s.  According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column3: Coos Bay has a warm-summer Mediterranean climate
column4: abbreviated Csb on climate maps
column5: but that borders on an oceanic climate
column6: due to the sheer amount of annual rainfall
column8: 651.0 mm) annually. Severe coastal storms (or gales) with hurricane-force winds occur frequently during the winter months
column9: while summers can be foggy. Snowfall is uncommon
column10: with less than an inch (2.54 cm) of snow annually.

column1: The Egyptian Theatre was part of a popular architectural movement and is the only Oregon movie house that still has its original theatre organ installation. Built in 1925
column3: but it was reopened shortly after by a nonprofit agency.  Closed again in 2011
column4: the Egyptian Theater Preservation Association and the Coos Bay Urban Renewal Agency were successful in raising enough money to reopen in June 2014.

column10: including the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area
column11: which brings approximately 1.5 million visitors each year. The ocean beaches near Coos Bay are devoid of the level of development seen on other areas of the Oregon Coast
column12: due to much of the coastline being designated state and county parks. Across the entrance bar to Coos Bay from the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area lie the rugged cliffs and pocket beaches of Bastendorf Beach County Park
column15: Shore Acres State Park and Cape Arago State Park. Approximately 11 miles (18 km) southwest of Coos Bay is the South Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve and approximately 25 miles (40 km) east in the Coast Range is Golden and Silver Falls State Natural Area.

column1: The City of Coos Bay operates under a council–manager form of government. The Coos Bay City Council is composed of a mayor and six councilors who are elected citywide to serve four-year terms. The council is responsible for setting policy decisions and they in turn hire a city manager to oversee the day-to-day administrative functions of the city. Coos Bay operates its own library
column3: public works and police department. The fire department has two fire stations that are staffed 24 hours a day. There is a third station that is used to house additional apparatus.

column1: The federally recognized Confederated Tribes of Coos
column2: Lower Umpqua and Siuslaw Indians are headquartered in Coos Bay.

column1: Coos Bay is historically a Democratic stronghold. Every precinct within the city voted for Democrat Barack Obama in the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections.Coos Bay is represented in the United States House by Peter Defazio (D-Springfield) and in the Oregon Legislature by State Senator Arnie Roblan (D-Coos Bay) and State Representative Caddy McKeown (D-Coos Bay).
Coos Bay K–12 public education is served by the Coos Bay School District.
Southwestern Oregon Community College (or SWOCC) offers certificates and associate degrees
column2: and has a dual admissions programs in partnership with Oregon public universities.

column1: Oregon Institute of Marine Biology (or OIMB) is the marine station of the University of Oregon. It is in Charleston
column2: at the mouth of Coos Bay. This 100-acre (0.40 km2) marine station was first deeded to the University of Oregon in 1931.

column1: Coos Bay has the largest concentration of health care facilities on the Oregon Coast and serves as a regional hub for the Central and Southern Coasts
column2: as well as inland areas. Bay Area Hospital
column3: the largest hospital on the coast has 172 beds and is undergoing a 97
column4: 000-square-foot (9
column5: 000 m2) expansion. Other facilities in the city include North Bend Medical Center
column6: Oregon Coast Spine Institute
column8: South Coast Center for Cosmetic Surgery
column9: South Coast Orthopedic Associates and Southwest Physical Therapy.

column1: Coos Bay is located along U.S. Highway 101.
The Southwest Oregon Regional Airport (ICAO: KOTH
column2: IATA: OTH) is a public airport located in adjacent North Bend and is the 5th busiest airport in Oregon
column3: as well as the largest airport on the Oregon Coast. Currently (2014) the airport hosts general aviation and charter services
column4: as well as offering daily commercial flights to/from both San Francisco and Portland.

column1: Porter Stage Lines provides bus service from Coos Bay with several stops
column3: which has connections with Amtrak rail services and the Greyhound bus network. Porter Stage Lines then extends to Bend and ends at Ontario in eastern Oregon
column4: and then reverses the trip.

column1: Coos County Area Transit or CCAT provides daily loop service to 54 stops around Coos Bay and North Bend.

The Port of Coos Bay provides freight shipping services. The Central Oregon and Pacific Railroad operated the Coos Bay Rail Link linking the port to the national rail network. The line is now operated by Coos Bay Rail Link.
